channel.title: NPR Topics: News
channel.description: NPR news, audio, and podcasts. Coverage of breaking stories, national and world news, politics, business, science, technology, and extended coverage of major national and world events.
channel.copyright: Copyright 2024 NPR - For Personal Use Only

item.title: The U.S. is sending more warships to the Middle East as Israel steps up attacks
item.description: Tensions increase in the Middle East, as Israel expects an attack from Iran and its allies. Israel says it's killed several top commanders of Hamas, Hezbollah, and Islamic Jihad.
item.content:encoded: Tensions increase in the Middle East, as Israel expects an attack from Iran and its allies. Israel says it's killed several top commanders of Hamas, Hezbollah, and Islamic Jihad.
item.dc:creator: Jane Arraf

item.title: Thousands take to the streets in Nigerian cities to protest government policies
item.description: Nigerians in several major cities are protesting government economic policies that are causing inflation and hunger.
item.content:encoded: Nigerians in several major cities are protesting government economic policies that are causing inflation and hunger.
item.dc:creator: Emmanuel Akinwotu

item.title: Saturday Sports: A record-breaking week at the Olympics
item.description: NPR's Scott Simon and ESPN's Michelle Steele discuss the record breaking performances of the first week of the Olympics in Paris and look forward to the next week.
item.content:encoded: NPR's Scott Simon and ESPN's Michelle Steele discuss the record breaking performances of the first week of the Olympics in Paris and look forward to the next week.
item.dc:creator: Scott Simon

item.title: Women are taking part in a century-old Catholic festival for the first time
item.description: Until this year, women were not allowed to fully participate in a large religious festival in New Bedford, Mass. Then they threatened to sue.
item.content:encoded: Until this year, women were not allowed to fully participate in a large religious festival in New Bedford, Mass. Then they threatened to sue.
item.dc:creator: Jennette Barnes

item.title: A roundup of the Olympics on TV so far
item.description: Some lucky sports fans are in Paris, but most Olympics viewers are watching from home. NPR Pop Culture Critic Linda Holmes gives host Scott Simon her review of the broadcast coverage so far.
item.content:encoded: Some lucky sports fans are in Paris, but most Olympics viewers are watching from home. NPR Pop Culture Critic Linda Holmes gives host Scott Simon her review of the broadcast coverage so far.
item.dc:creator: Linda Holmes

item.title: Russian troops are gaining ground in eastern Ukraine
item.description: Russian forces are making small but steady gains in eastern Ukraine and seem to be targeting a key town. Ukraine is getting more Western weapons, but Russia still has more firepower and more troops.
item.content:encoded: Russian forces are making small but steady gains in eastern Ukraine and seem to be targeting a key town. Ukraine is getting more Western weapons, but Russia still has more firepower and more troops.
item.dc:creator: Greg Myre

item.title: Amtrak is set to carry more passengers than ever before this year
item.description: Amtrak is on its way to carrying more passengers this fiscal year than ever before. NPR's Scott Simon speaks with Reuters reporter David Shepardson about why that is.
item.content:encoded: Amtrak is on its way to carrying more passengers this fiscal year than ever before. NPR's Scott Simon speaks with Reuters reporter David Shepardson about why that is.
item.dc:creator: Scott Simon

item.title: In 1968, the DNC was also held in Chicago. That's where the similarities end
item.description: With the Democratic National Convention returning to Chicago this month, media historian Michael Socolow warns against drawing parallels between 1968 and now. He talks with NPR's Scott Simon.
item.content:encoded: With the Democratic National Convention returning to Chicago this month, media historian Michael Socolow warns against drawing parallels between 1968 and now. He talks with NPR's Scott Simon.
item.dc:creator: Scott Simon

item.title: How Harris entering the presidential race will impact those who were on the fence
item.description: NPR's Scott Simon talks to Rich Thau, who studies swing states, about some key voters this election: those who supported former South Carolina Gov. Nikki Haley in primaries, and "double disapprovers."
item.content:encoded: NPR's Scott Simon talks to Rich Thau, who studies swing states, about some key voters this election: those who supported former South Carolina Gov. Nikki Haley in primaries, and "double disapprovers."
item.dc:creator: Scott Simon

item.title: Stocks fell after weak jobs report. Are we heading for a recession?
item.description: The stock market tumbled Friday after a weaker-than-expected jobs report. Together with a gloomy factory survey, the news has investors worried about a broader economic slowdown.
item.content:encoded: The stock market tumbled Friday after a weaker-than-expected jobs report. Together with a gloomy factory survey, the news has investors worried about a broader economic slowdown.
item.dc:creator: Scott Horsley
